intro: Semecarpus albescens, commonly known as the Indian chestnut or bael tree, is a deciduous tree native to the Indian subcontinent. It belongs to the family Sapindaceae and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The tree produces a large, woody fruit that splits open to reveal a sweet, edible pulp surrounding a hard, chestnut-like seed. It is often found in moist, tropical and subtropical regions, growing in dense forests and along riverbanks. The plant has various uses, including medicinal applications and as a source of timber and food.
